thread.title_full: You'll be sweet on Halkidiki as city in northern Greece will leave you buzzing - Mirror Online

author: Margot Huysman
title: You'll be sweet on Halkidiki as city in northern Greece will leave you buzzing
text:
Picture yourself on holiday in gorgeous Greece ... On a beach on one of the idyllic islands, perhaps? Or exploring the ancient sights of Athens?
But there’s a place in the north of the country – hopefully now recovering from the financial crisis – that offers all that and more.
Stunning architecture, fabulous beaches and the warmest of welcomes... so welcome to Halkidiki.
I flew in to Thessaloniki – Greece’s second city – and headed first to the Gulf of Strymonikos and Olympiada, a lovely fishing village which is an ideal starting point to visit the area.
Here, you are right by the sea and only a few minutes’ walk from Aristotle’s birthplace.
It’s well situated for a visit to Mount Athos, also known as the Holy Mountain, on one of Halkidiki’s three narrow peninsulas.
However, it’s an autonomous monastic area with 20 monasteries and is only open to men.
Scenery: Margot by waterfall in the forest of Varvara
Whether one of those visiting men has been Russia’s president Vladimir Putin... who knows? But the Kormilitsa wines from this region have been adopted at the Kremlin!
On your way from Thessaloniki to Olympiada, make a stop at Arnea.
The village, home to a few thousand people, is a typical mountain town, with small cobbled streets, secret passageways and old house facades, and many buildings have signs on the outside explaining their history.
The honey in Arnea is famous in the region, and rightly so. I recommend popping into a local shop and picking up a couple of pots (the honey made from chestnut flowers is specially good).
And while you are there, do try a bit of Mountovina, an alcoholic drink made from honey – it will certainly clear any stuffiness you might have picked up on the flight.
After your quick honey pitstop, visit Arnea’s church of Agios Stefanos. Remains of an ancient church were found under the current building and as you walk through you can see them from above, protected by a layer of glass.
Harbour: Halkidiki
All this sightseeing was building an appetite and chef Dimitrios Bakatsianos’s fabulous restaurant beckoned. The place is hidden away in a forest of trees, making it an ideal spot to shelter from the searing sun ( bakatsianos.gr/en/ ).
Do as the Greeks do and order a variety of plates to share across the table. We piled in to forest ­potatoes cooked in a clay pot, with cheese, egg and truffle (€8.50), and sausage (€7.50) on which you squeeze a little lemon juice – unlike anything you will find at home. And the roasted feta cheese (€3.50) is something else entirely.
Enjoy your meal surrounded by nature with a bottle of local wine. If you still have space after all that food, the dessert menu is well worth a look – ice cream encased
in little filaments of pastry finishes off the meal perfectly.
I was staying at the Hotel Germany in Olympiada, situated ideally by the beach. The setting is perfect for a glass of Tsipouro brandy in the evening – actually it seems to be offered at all times of the day!
It’s a family-run hotel that will make you feel at ease, with the sound of the waves lulling you to sleep. Breakfast is served on the terrace, a mix of local yogurt, bread, jams and pastries. The dining room gives you a glimpse into the open kitchen, so you can watch your food being prepared.
Try the local mussels, either steamed or deep fried. They are the best I’ve ever had (and I say this as a Belgian).
And if you like your seafood, the octopus with figs cooked in wine is unlike anything you will have tried before – but it is magnificent.
Rugged: Coastline near Mount Athos
The local mussels are known for their taste and size – the warm waters help them develop – and I headed to a mussel farm in Olympiada for a tour.
Here, you get to see the farming in action and, if you’re up for it, try a mussel straight from the sea – they have a taste not unlike oysters. If you can, arrange for the visit to include lunch.
If you want to burn off a few calories you’re in luck as this area is ideal for walks – and ancient Stagira, Aristotle’s birthplace, is great for roaming among the ruins, enjoying the sea views and doing a little philosophising yourself.
Inland also offers some idyllic locations and I visited the forest of Varvara, which
is famous for its pair of waterfalls in the trees.
It’s perfect for a picnic in the beautiful surroundings – maybe pick up some
delicacies from the nearby town of Varvara itself.
And if you are feeling a little too hot, dip your feet and ankles in the clear water. Then find a large rock, lie back, relax and take in as much of the peace and quiet as possible.
From the food to the forest to the sea and the scenery, you’ll struggle to leave this part of Halkidiki.
But a solution is at hand.
Simply have a sip of water at the fountain in Arnea’s main square; legend has it that whoever drinks it will stay for ever...
Get there Ramblers Holidays has 7nt h/b walking holidays in eastern Halkidiki from £899pp inc flights from Gatwick on Oct 17, transfers, accommodation at the Hotel Liotopi in Olympiada ( hotel-liotopi.gr/en/ ) and guided walks. ramblersholidays.co.uk
Rooms at the Hotel Germany in Olympiada start at £91pn h/b in Sept based on 2 sharing. hotel-germany.gr
easyJet flies to Thessaloniki from Manchester and Gatwick. Fares in Sept start at £33.24 one way based on 2 people on the same booking. easyjet.com
Tourist info: mountathosarea.org and visitgreece.gr
Time zone: UK +2hrs
Currency: Euro £1 = 1.39
Best time to go: Perfect late summer sunshine getaway in September
